item.title: Day 14: Lists are 99.7% of the job
item.description: 99.7% of software development in one requirement A user should be able to view a list of items. ‚Äî @samccone Listen to Sam. Lists make Apps‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
99.7% of software development in one requirement
A user should be able to view a list of items.
‚Äî @samccone

Listen to Sam. Lists make Apps.

Array of sunshine

The children of a component can be an array.

<div>{[1, 2, 3]}</div>

The resulting DOM will look like this:

<div>123</div>

Because components are just functions, arrays can hold components.

<ul>{[<li>one</li>, <li>two</li>]}</ul>

Resulting in DOM like this:

<ul>
  <li>one</li>
  <li>two</li>
</ul>

Data in, components out

Let‚Äôs use map() to turn an array of data into an array of components.

const countdown = [3, 2, 1];
const millenialCountdown = countdown.map(n => <strong>{n} üëè</strong>);

Let‚Äôs use that technique to show the abilities of our Pokemon.

<ul>
  {this.state.character.abilities.map(ability => 
    <li>{ability.ability.name}</li>
  )}
</ul>

(The API is a little redundant here. Sorry)

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and explore arrays as children.

  • Inspect the API and render another list you find.
  • Arrays have a lot of methods. Try filtering or sorting the abilities.

item.title: Day 13: Gotta fetch 'em all
item.description: Today, we start with a new component! üéä üéâ üéä üéâ Pokemon Take a stab at writing this component in a new sandbox before reading the next‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Today, we start with a new component!

üéä üéâ üéä üéâ

Pokemon

Take a stab at writing this component in a new sandbox before reading the next section.

  • Name the component Pokemon
  • Make sure it‚Äôs a component that can hold state
  • Use { character: null } as the inital state
  • Take an id prop. It‚Äôll be the index of the Pokemon we fetch.

  • Render conditionally:

    • If state has a character, render this.state.character.name
    • Otherwise render the message ...loading

(At this point, it should always render ...loading)

Fetch a Pokemon

You got it? Great!

In the workspace below, I‚Äôve included a fetchPokemon function. We‚Äôll use it in the next section.

Meet componentDidMount

componentDidMount is a special power our component has. Speaking technically, it‚Äôs a method on our component class.

When defined, it‚Äôs called when a Pokemon is mounted into the DOM.

componentDidMount() {
  fetchPokemon(1, (character) => this.setState({ character: character }))
}

componentDidMount is the ideal place to fetch data from a server.

Tinker with it

  • Fetch a pokemon with a different id
  • Log messages from componentDidMount and render observe the order in the console.

class ClapCounter extends React.Component {

      {this.props.children}

item.title: Day 11: Use expressions for conditional rendering
item.description: You can‚Äôt use if/else statements in `render. In those curly-braces, you can only use expressions. Fortunately, you got a couple options‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
You can‚Äôt use if/else statements in `render.

render() {
  return (
    <div>{/* no if/else */}</div>
  )
}

In those curly-braces, you can only use expressions. Fortunately, you got a couple options.

Tern or Burn

The ternary operator is a syntax for conditional expressions.

// just like if/else
someCondition ? 'shown if truthy' : 'shown if falsy'

Short circuit

Short-circuit evaluation works too.

someCondition && 'shown only if truthy' // if
someCondition || 'shown only if falsy' // unless

Clap on, clap off, The Clapper

Our ClapCounter (from the 9th) acts like every clap is the first clap.
It just isn‚Äôt true.

Let‚Äôs use short-circuit evaluation render the message only when there are 0 claps. Let‚Äôs also render the number of claps only when there are 1 or more.

<div>
  <button ... >
    {this.state.clapCount >= 0 && this.state.clapCount} üëè
  </button>

  {this.state.clapCount === 0 && <i> be the first to clap</i>}
</div>

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and explore conditional rendering.

  • Use a ternary to add an alternative message (condition ? truthy : falsy)
  • Get crazy and use what we‚Äôve learned about events and state to conditionally display a message on hover. You can do it!

item.title: Day 10: setState is a food truck
item.description: When you set down with set state, you‚Äôre might think state is set immediately. It isn‚Äôt. There‚Äôs a leak! setState has a naming problem. You‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
When you set down with set state, you‚Äôre might think state is set immediately.

It isn‚Äôt.

this.setState({ count: 1 });
console.log(this.state.count); // <= Probably not what you expected

There‚Äôs a leak!

setState has a naming problem.

You‚Äôre right to think that setState sets state immediately. It‚Äôs in the name.
But only because it beats a more descriptive alternative like enqueueStateTransition

For a technical read of what‚Äôs going on, read the setState doc.

We‚Äôre gonna talk about hotdogs.

A fast-food mental model

Food trucks provide a great mental model for setState. Here are some attributes they share:

Asyncronous

Food trucks act asyncronously‚Äîa big word for ‚ÄúI move on while they make food.‚Äù

I order.
I pay.
I step back and read twitter.
Other people order and pay.
5-10 minutes later someone hands me food.

Queued

Orders are queued but not a first-in, first-out queue.
Food trucks need to be fast so they batch and prioritize.

Prioritized

You like hot fries? Me too.
So when that fryer timer fires, fry orders get prioritized.

(say that 5 times fast)

Batched

While I imagine a chef decisively considering exactly how much Tabouli to garnish my ‚ÄúLambda Lambda Lambda‚Äù with, it‚Äôs not how food trucks work.

Scott wipes his sweaty brow, looks ahead, see 5 orders of Lambda Lambda Lambda, and they get batched for quick processing.

What does this have to do with anything?

setState is a food truck.

Orders get queued.
Work gets batched and prioritized for speed.
And it all happens asyncronously.

On the next render, you can pick-up your piping hot Lambda Lambda Lambda and fries.

item.title: Day 9: Set state dynamically
item.description: If you want to set state dynamically, use a function . We give setState an anonymous function to be called with state . Our function‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
If you want to set state dynamically, use a function.

this.setState(function(previousState) {
  return { someProp: previousState.someProp + 1 }
})

We give setState an anonymous function to be called with state. Our function takes that state and returns a new object with new values derived from the old.

Concise but not clear

This is how I write setState(fn) in a modern code base. It‚Äôs how you‚Äôre likely to see it in the real world.

this.setState((previousState) =>
  ({ clapCount: previousState.clapCount + 1 })
)

Arrow functions have implicit returns but if the return type is an object, you must wrap it in partheses.

Why previousState not currentState?

While setState does update state‚Äîeventually‚Äîit does so asyncronously and in batches.

Because of that implementation detail, the state that your function recieves might not be the current state.

I‚Äôm so confused‚Ä¶

Yeah. It‚Äôs very confusing.

Tomorrow let‚Äôs implement our own state setter. You‚Äôll get a better idea of how setState sausage is made.

(I‚Äôll use an actual sausage to illustrate)

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and set some state with functions.

  • Experiment with syntax. Use both function declarations and arrow function expressions to dynamically set state. Does one seem clearer than the other?
  • For fun, use destructuring assignment to unpack values from the state object.

item.title: Day 8: Set state statically
item.description: Managing state is hard. I‚Äôll take four days to cover the React APIs for setting state. So don‚Äôt read today‚Äôs lesson without coming back for‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Managing state is hard.

I‚Äôll take four days to cover the React APIs for setting state.
So don‚Äôt read today‚Äôs lesson without coming back for set state dynamically and setState is a food truck.

setState is GrrrrREAT!

Meet setState().

this.setState({ someProp: newState })

This is a special power our components get by extending React.Component.
When called, setState updates the local state object and re-renders the component.

Set state statically

Continue yesterday‚Äôs example and replace the alert with a proper state change.

<button
  type="button"
  onClick={() =>
    this.setState({ clapCount: 1 })
  }
>
  {this.state.clapCount}
  {' '}üëè
</button>

Limitations

Above, we call setState() with a new state object.

There are two ways to use setState. This one is easy to understand but quickly limiting. We set clapCount with a static value but how do we use a dynamic value? How do we keep our counter counting, transitioning current state to the next state?

Tomorrow we‚Äôll learn how to transition state.

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and set some state.

  • Change value you set clapCount to. Get crazy; try a string.
  • Create another component that counts something else. üëçs, üôås, anything!
  • Keep the counter counting. Try your hand at making state changes dynamic.

item.title: Day 7: State of mind
item.description: Being sexy is all about attitude‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs a state of mind. ‚Äî Amisha Patel One of the special powers of class components is their ability to‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Being sexy is all about attitude‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs a state of mind.
‚Äî Amisha Patel

One of the special powers of class components is their ability to hold state.

With state, you get interactivity. No state, no interactivity. So component state isn‚Äôt just a feature, it‚Äôs the feature.

How I do dat state hawtnez?

Start with an initial state. Do this in the constructor of your class components.

class MyStateOfMind extends React.Component {
  constructor() {
    super();
    this.state = { sexy: true }
  }
  ...

In create-react-app projects, use this ESNext syntax to avoid the constructor noise.

class MyStateOfMind extends React.Component {
  state = { sexy: true }
  ...

Back to Claps

Let‚Äôs add a clapCount state to the ClapsCounter we worked on yesterday.

class ClapCounter extends React.Component {
  state = { clapCount: 0 }
  
  render() {
    return (
      <div>
        <button
          type="button"
          onClick={() =>
            alert(this.state.clapCount + 1 + " claps")
          }
        >
          {this.state.clapCount}{' '}üëè
        </button>
        <i> be the first to clap</i>
      </div>
    );
  }
}

Stay sexy, nerds

Now you know how to initialize state and your state of mind will always be sexy.

As for our clapCount state, it‚Äôll be changing tomorrow‚Ä¶

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and play with state.

  • Change the initial state from 0 to 100. Does the alert read 101 claps?
  • Add more state properties. Try strings, numbers, function expressions, whatever you want.

item.title: Day 6: Events aren't events
item.description: Look at HTML. It lets you handle DOM events inline. I could tell the sordid history that landed this in the ‚Äúbad practice‚Äù bucket but we‚Äôd‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Look at HTML. It lets you handle DOM events inline.

<button
  onmousenter="alert('imma...')"
  onmousleave="alert('just passing through.')"
  onclick="alert('do that thing you do!')"
>Do something</button>

I could tell the sordid history that landed this in the ‚Äúbad practice‚Äù bucket but we‚Äôd both be bored.

Suffice to say, folks bent on ‚Äúgood practices‚Äù had to jump through hoops to implement safe, reusable, cross-browser event handlers.

React Events don‚Äôt share these trade-offs.

Adding event handlers in React

Let‚Äôs add an onClick (remember to camelCase) to our ClapsCounter from yesterday.

<button
  type="button"
  onClick={() => alert(1 + " claps!")}
/>
  üëè
</button>

Look, Ma! No strings!

First, you‚Äôll notice that we‚Äôre not using strings anymore üôå üôå üôå

This is a theme in React: fewer strings, more JavaScript.

Look, Ma! No DOM handlers!

What the fish? Where did our event handler go?

React did the work of making this ‚Äúbad practice‚Äù a ‚Äúgood practice‚Äù by adding our event handler at the top of the document.

This is another React theme: best practices don‚Äôt have to be complicated practices.

But really, what happened?

Magic üîÆüëª

If you must know, you can read more about React‚Äôs Event handling magic and Synthetic Events.

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and play with events.

  • Add a few mouse events.
  • For kicks, add a text input. Anything weird happen? Like you can‚Äôt type in it? Spooooooky.

item.title: Day 5: Components can use classes for special powers
item.description: Some components have to be special. Those components get defined with class . It‚Äôs not much to look at now. We‚Äôll fill it in this week‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Some components have to be special. Those components get defined with class.

class ClapCounter extends React.Component {
  render() {
    return (
      <div>
        üëè <i> be the first to clap</i>
      </div>
    );
  }
}

It‚Äôs not much to look at now. We‚Äôll fill it in this week.

Some ground rules

Component classes extend React.Component and define a render() method.

For comparison, here‚Äôs what Greeting looks like as a component class.

class Greeting extends React.Component {
  render() {
    return (
      <h1>Hello {this.props.name}.</h1>
    );
  }
}

What speshul powerz they got?!

Unlike function components, class components have an instance‚Äîthis. This gives us lifecycle methods and state APIs for some seriously cool interactivity.

Sooooooo much ahead!

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and play with component classes.

  • Convert Greeting to a component class and back to a function.
  • Define a new component using class. Be sure not to forget extends, render() and this.

item.title: Day 4: Props are function arguments
item.description: If components are functions and functions take arguments, components should take arguments. They do! In React we call component arguments‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
If components are functions and functions take arguments, components should take arguments.

They do!

In React we call component arguments props.

Where do props come from?

Props are authored like HTML attributes. Say you want to add a name prop. Add it as an ‚Äúattribute‚Äù where you use the component:

<Greeting name="bulbasaur" />

Now how do I use ‚Äòem in the component?

React puts props in a single object. And that object is conveniently, the first argument of our component function.

Once you have the props object, you can interpolate values in with {}.

function Greeting(props) {
  return <h1>Hello {props.name}</h1>;
}

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and play with props.

Be creative and have fun!

item.title: Day 3: Components are functions
item.description: Components are just functions. ü§Ø How do I write said component functions? Easy. Here‚Äôs one that spits out our Hello üéÑ wherever used. How‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Components are just functions.

ü§Ø

How do I write said component functions?

Easy.

Here‚Äôs one that spits out our Hello üéÑ wherever used.

function Greeting() {
  return <h1>Hello üéÑ</h1>;
}

How do I use said component functions?

JSX has you covered. Just use the function name like an HTML tag.

<Greeting />
<Greeting></Greeting>

That‚Äôs it?

Pretty much, but here‚Äôs something to remember - Capitalize your Custom Components. If you don‚Äôt, JSX transformers assume you meant a native DOM element.

item.title: Day 2: JSX 4 LYFE
item.description: People like to make hay about JSX . Don‚Äôt get your undies in a bunched. All it does is make these two lines equivalent: How does HTML work‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
People like to make hay about JSX.

Don‚Äôt get your undies in a bunched. All it does is make these two lines equivalent:

// No-JSX
React.createElement("h1", {}, "Hello üéÑ")

// YAAAAS!!!-JSX
<h1>Hello üéÑ</h1>

How does HTML work in JavaScript?

Don‚Äôt think of it like HTML, it isn‚Äôt.

JSX is just a authoring nice-to-have. But it‚Äôs not something that works in the browser. It must be transformed to React.createElement() calls before the browser can run it. Most apps use projects like Babel or TypeScript to handle that.

Why JSX?

JSX is optional but it has community consensus. There‚Äôs a certain harmony to spec‚Äôing React elements in a syntax similar to HTML.

Gotchas

JSX isn‚Äôt all ü¶Ñs and üåàs.

Lowercase attributes like class, onclick, autofocus, and tabindex become camelCased className, onClick, autoFocus, and tabIndex respectively.

They can also take any JavaScript expression.

This takes time to get used to. The examples below are identical.

HTML

<button
  type="button"
  autofocus
  class="some-button"
  onclick="alert('HTML!')"
>Hello üéÑ</button>

JSX

<button
  type="button"
  autoFocus
  className="some-button"
  onClick={() => alert('JSX!')}
>Hello üéÑ</button>

JS

React.createElement(
  'button',
  {
    type: 'button',
    autoFocus: true,
    className: 'some-button',
    onClick: () => alert('JS!'),
  },
  'Hello üéÑ'
)

Tinker with it

Use the workspace below and play with the JSX.

  • Try using class instead of className. What error do you get?
  • Nest a couple elements inside of each other. Did they render as expected? How would you write the same using React.createElement()?

item.title: Day 1: Hello üéÑ
item.description: In C , programs have a main() function. It‚Äôs where programs starts. React apps are similar; on the web they start with ReactDOM.render‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
In C, programs have a main() function. It‚Äôs where programs starts.

React apps are similar; on the web they start with ReactDOM.render().

ReactDOM.render(someReactComponent, someDOMNode)

WTF is ReactDOM?

React is used all over‚Äîweb, mobile, desktop, VR, appliances. Lots of places.

Instead of stuffing all those smarts into one enormous library, each platform has a partner library.

On the web, that‚Äôs ReactDOM.

We use React to create components and ReactDOM to render them into the DOM.

ReactDOM.render(
  React.createElement('h1', {}, 'Hello üéÑ'),
  document.getElementById('root')
)

Tinker with it

  • Comment out the import statements. What errors do you get?

  • Put some values in the empty object (second argument). What happens? What errors do you get?
